introduction.p: As pictured in the applet, a skateboarder who is 6 feet tall rides under a 15 foot tall lamppost at a constant rate of 3 feet per second. We are interested in understanding how fast his shadow is changing at various points in time.

statement.p: Draw an appropriate right triangle that represents a snapshot in time of the skateboarder, lamppost, and his shadow. Let x denote the horizontal distance from the base of the lamppost to the skateboarder and s represent the length of his shadow. Label these quantities, as well as the skateboarder's height and the lamppost's height on the diagram.

hint.p: Note that the lengths of the legs of the right triangle will be 15 for the vertical one and x + s for the horizontal one.

statement.p: Observe that the skateboarder and the lamppost represent parallel line segments in the diagram, and thus similar triangles are present. Use similar triangles to establish an equation that relates x and s.

hint.p: The small triangle formed by the skateboarder and his shadow, with legs 6 and s is similar to the large triangle that has the lamppost as one of its legs.

solution.p:
The small triangle formed by the skateboarder and his shadow, with legs of length 6 and s is similar to the large triangle that has the lamppost as one of its legs (length 15) and horizontal leg of length x + s. Because the ratios of the lengths of the legs of these two triangles is equal, we have
\frac{s}{6} = \frac{s+x}{15} . Simplifying, we have 15s = 6s + 6x, so that 9s = 2x, or most simply, 3s = 2x.

statement.p: Use your work in (b) to find an equation that relates \frac{dx}{dt} and \frac{ds}{dt}.

hint.p: Simplify the equation in (b) as much as possible before differentiating implicitly with respect to t.

solution.p: Differentiating with respect to t, it is immediate that 3 \frac{ds}{dt} = 2\frac{dx}{dt}.

statement.p: At what rate is the length of the skateboarder's shadow increasing at the instant the skateboarder is 8 feet from the lamppost?

solution.p: Since \frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{2}{3} \frac{dx}{dt}, and \frac{dx}{dt} = 3, it follows \frac{ds}{dt} = 2 for every value of t (and x). Thus, \left. \frac{ds}{dt} \right|_{x=8} = 2 feet per second.

statement.p: As the skateboarder's distance from the lamppost increases, is his shadow's length increasing at an increasing rate, increasing at a decreasing rate, or increasing at a constant rate?

hint.p: Does the equation that relates \frac{dx}{dt} and \frac{ds}{dt} involve x? Is \frac{dx}{dt} changing or constant?

solution.p: Because \frac{ds}{dt} is constant, the shadow's length is increasing at a constant rate (irrespective of the distance from the skateboarder to the lamppost).

statement.p: Which is moving more rapidly: the skateboarder or the tip of his shadow? Explain, and justify your answer.

hint.p: Let y represent the location of the tip of the shadow, so that y = x + s.

answer.p: Let y represent the location of the tip of the shadow; \frac{dy}{dt} = 5 feet/sec.

solution.p: Let y represent the location of the tip of the shadow, so that y = x + s. Observe that we can now compute \frac{dy}{dt} in terms of \frac{dx}{dt} and \frac{ds}{dt}, with \frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{ds}{dt} = 3 + 2 = 5 feet/sec, and hence the tip of the shadow is moving more rapidly than the skateboarder himself.
